Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You see a coworker about to walk under a suspended load, and you must shout to warn them instantly.
Story: I stood at the edge of the construction site, my phone buzzing in my pocket. My partner’s messages were desperate, raw with pain after losing his father last night. He needed me—my words, my comfort, my presence. I wanted to drop everything, to call him, to be the shoulder he could lean on. But the clang of machinery snapped me back. I saw a coworker, distracted, stepping right under a heavy load swaying above. My heart pounded. I knew the rules: safety first, always. I had to shout, to break the silence, to keep him safe. But my mind was split—my partner’s grief echoing in my ears, the weight of his need pressing on me, while the urgency of the site demanded my focus. I felt torn, my throat tight, caught between the person I loved and the responsibility I couldn’t ignore.
